summary: This is an email chain from December 4, 2008, discussing a motion to correct Jeffrey Epstein's sentence and questions about work release procedures. It involves Assistant U.S. Attorney West, defense attorney Roy Black, and references to Judges Pucillo and McSorley.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: He is the sender of the email containing the draft motion to correct the sentence and is communicating with the Assistant U.S. Attorney about procedural matters.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney West
persons.context: The recipient of the email who is asking questions about who should be notified regarding misstatements in Epstein's work release application and how victims can voice concerns.

persons.name: Judge Pucillo
persons.context: Described as a retired judge who handled the plea agreement for Epstein's case on a specific day because it had to be done then.

persons.name: McSorley
persons.context: The judge whose docket was handled by Judge Pucillo; his order states that all division W cases for work release are at the sheriff's discretion.

persons.name: Jack
persons.context: Mentioned as stating that Judge McSorley entered a new sentencing order without notice to anyone.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the motion to correct sentence and the work release application being discussed.

connections.description: Roy Black is drafting a motion to correct Epstein's sentence, indicating he is acting as Epstein's defense attorney.
The prosecutor is involved in procedural questions regarding Epstein's work release and victim notifications.
They are communicating via email about the motion and work release procedures, showing professional legal correspondence.
Judge Pucillo handled Epstein's plea agreement on a specific day due to scheduling constraints.
Epstein's case was in Judge McSorley's division (W), and McSorley's order governed work release discretion.

events.title: Discussion of Motion to Correct Sentence
events.description: Email correspondence about a draft motion to correct Jeffrey Epstein's sentence and questions regarding work release procedures.

events.title: Entry of New Sentencing Order
events.description: According to 'Jack', Judge McSorley entered a new sentencing order for Epstein without notice to anyone.

keyFacts: A motion to correct Jeffrey Epstein's sentence was being drafted by his attorney Roy Black in December 2008.
Prosecutors were seeking clarification on who should be notified about potential misstatements in Epstein's work release application and how victims could voice concerns.
Judge Pucillo, a retired judge, handled Epstein's plea agreement on a specific day because it had to occur then.
Epstein's case was in judicial division W, and according to Judge McSorley's order, work release decisions for such cases were at the sheriff's discretion.
An individual named 'Jack' claimed Judge McSorley entered a new sentencing order for Epstein without providing notice to anyone.
